class pyez_stats.Data(Xs: list)[source]

Instantiate a Data object. Acts as an array with multiple methods for operating on data.

Parameters:

Xs (np.ndarray) – Data.

bayesian_statistic(likelihood: str = None, prior: str = None) → Bayesian[source]

Method used to perform Bayesian statistical analysis.

Parameters:

  • likelihood (str) – The Model used to compute the likelihood function that encorporates new data in bayesian statistics.

  • prior – The Model used to base an assumption of what the data/probability already is. Usually Gamma or Beta.

Tyoe prior:

str

Returns:

Instance of Bayesian object used for Bayesian statistics.

Return type:

bs.Bayesian

cdf(value: float, parameter1: float = None, parameter2: float = None) → float[source]

Calculates the cumulative probability of a certain value for the model specified.

Parameters:

  • value (float) – Value we want to find the probability of.

  • parameter1 (float) – Optional expected value parameter.

  • parameter2 (float) – Optional variance parameter.

Returns:

Probabilty of achieving up to a certain result.

Return type:

float

hypothesis_test(model: str = None) → HypothesisTesting[source]

Method used to perfrom multiple statistical hypothesis testing functions. Once called you can use any method from the Hypothesis test class.

Parameters:

model (str) – If instance attribute model has not been set you may pass it in hear.

Returns:

Instance of HypothesisTesting object.

Return type:

ht.HypothesisTesting

kurtosis(p: float = None) → float[source]

Calculates the kurtosis of the given data set.

Parameters:

p (float) – Parameter for kurtosis calculation if required.

Returns:

Kurtosis of the data set

Return type:

float

lamb_hat() → float[source]

Calculates the parameter lambda from our given data set if it fits the correct distribution.

Returns:

lambda parameter.

Return type:

float

linear_regression(data: ndarray = None)[source]

Method used to perform a linear regression on Our data and another variable. The data originally passed into the Data class is our response variable.

Parameters:

data (np.ndarray) – Data used as explanatory variable.

Returns:

A linear regression object that has multiple methods for performing a linear regression.

Return type:

reg.LinearRegression

mean() → float[source]

Calculates the mean of the data set.

Returns:

Mean of the data set.

Return type:

float

multiple_linear_regression(*args)[source]

Method used to perform a multiple linear regression on Our data and multiple other variables. The data originally passed into the Data class is our response variable.

Parameters:

args (np.ndarray) – arguments are multiple arrays of data.

Returns:

A multiple linear regression object that has multiple methods for performing and plotting a multiple linear regression.

Return type:

reg.MultipleLinearRegression

p_hat() → float[source]

Calculates the parameter p_hat from our given data set if it fits the correct distribution.

Returns:

P hat parameter.

Return type:

float

pca(*args)[source]

Method used to conduct Principle Component Analysis on a variable amount of data.

Parameters:

args (np.ndarray) – arguments are multiple arrays of data.

Returns:

An instance of a PCA object.

Return type:

PCA

pdf(value: float, parameter1: float = None, parameter2: float = None) → float[source]

Calculates the probability of a certain value for the model specified.

Parameters:

  • value (float) – Value we want to find the probability of.

  • parameter1 (float) – Optional expected value parameter.

  • parameter2 (float) – Optional variance parameter.

Returns:

Probability of achieving a certain result.

Return type:

float

Sets the probability model that will be used in our analysis.

Parameters:

model (str) – Model name.

Returns:

Instance of Distribution model.

Return type:

ds.Distribution

class pyez_stats.Gaussian(Xs: ndarray = None)[source]

Instantiate an object that represents a Gaussian distribution. Inherits A likelihhod class used for calculations involving maximum likelihood estimation.

Parameters:

Xs (np.ndarray) – Array used to hold data.

cdf(value=None) → float[source]

Method used to calculate the cdf of passed values.

Parameters:

value (float) – Value we want to find the cumulative probability of.

Returns:

Cdf of a Gaussian distribution.

Return type:

float

confidence_interval(percent: float = 95, parameter: str = None) → list[source]

Uses ConfidenceInterval class to calculate the confidence interval of Gaussian data.

Parameters:

  • percent (float) – Defines the percent of the distribution we want to calculate the confidence interval for.

  • parameter (str) – Optional used to define a specific parameter or not.

Returns:

Confidence interval for Gaussian distributed data.

Return type:

ConfidenceInterval

fisher_information() → float[source]

Method that calculates the mean fisher information of our data.

Returns:

Mean fisher information.

Return type:

float

kurtosis() → float[source]

Method that calculates the kurtosis of our distribution.

Returns:

Kurtosis of our data.

Return type:

float

mean() → float[source]

Method used to calculate the mean of our provided data.

Returns:

Mean of the data.

Return type:

float

pdf(value: float = None, mu: float = None, var: float = None) → float[source]

Method used to calculate the probability density function for Gaussian data.

Parameters:

  • value (float) – Value we want to find the probability of.

  • mu (float) – Optional parameter if the population mean is known.

  • var (float) – Optional parameter if the population variance is known.

Returns:

Probability of passed value.

Return type:

float

percentile(percent: float = None, standardize: bool = False) → float[source]

Calculate the percentile of a Gaussian distribution.

Parameters:

  • percent (float) – Specify the percentile of the distribution we want to find the value of.

  • standardize (bool) – If True calculates the percentile of the standard normal distribution.

Returns:

Percent of the Gaussian distribution.

Return type:

float

skewness() → float[source]

Method that calculates the skewness of our distribution.

Returns:

The skewness of our distribution.

Return type:

float

var(unbiasedVar: bool = False) → float[source]

Method for calculating the variance of a distribution.

Parameters:

unbiasedVar (bool) – Used to specify if we want our variance to be biased or unbiased.

Returns:

Variance of our data.

Return type:

float

var_fisher_information() → float[source]

Method that calculates the variance fisher information for our data.

Returns:

Variance of the fisher information.

Return type:

float

var_mu_hat() → float[source]

Helper function used to calculate the variance hat of our data.

Returns:

Variance hat used for calculations in other methods.

Return type:

float

  • lamb (float) – Optional lambda parameter if population lambda is known.

  • parameter (str) – Optional used to define a specific parameter or not.

Lambda parameter.

lamb (float) – Parameter of our distribution.

Returns:

Average of our random exponential data

Return type:

float

  • lamb (float) – Optional lambda parameter if population lambda hat is known.

class pyez_stats.Binomial(Xs: ndarray = None)[source]

Instantiate an object that represents a Binomial distribution. Inherits A likelihhod class used for calculations involving maximum likelihood estimation. Note we us np.random.binomial(1, p, size) to get random data for this, it is important that the first parameter is 1 or else the calculations will be wrong

Parameters:

Xs (np.ndarray) – Array used to hold data.

cdf(x: int = None, p: float = None, n: float = None) → float[source]

Method used to calculate the cdf of our distribution.

Parameters:

  • x (int) – number of successes we calculate the cdf of.

  • p (float) – Optional parameter if population p is known.

  • n (int) – Number of trials ran in the experiment.

Returns:

Cumulative probability of value.

Return type:

float

confidence_interval(percent: float = 95, **null) → list[source]

Uses binomial confidence interval from our confidence interval class to calculate the confidence interval of our distribution.

Parameters:

  • percent (float) – Defines the percent of the distribution we want to calculate the confidence interval for.

  • null (Dictionary) – Optional used to define a specific parameter or not.

Returns:

Confidence interval for Exponentially distributed data.

Return type:

ConfidenceInterval

p (float) – Optional p parameter if the population parameter is known.

  • p (float) – Optional parameter if population p is known.

  • n (int) – Number of trials ran in the experiment.

Probability of value.

  • t_test (bool) – True if we are conducting a t test.

  • left_tail (bool) – True if we are conducting a left tailed test.

  • right_tail (bool) – True if we are conducting a right tailed test.

  • sigma (float) – used if our p value requries a known variance.

class pyez_stats.Bayesian(Xs: ndarray, likelihood: str = None, prior: str = None)[source]

Instantiate a Bayesian object for Bayesian statistical analysis.

Parameters:

  • Xs (np.ndarray) – Data used for Bayesian statistical analysis.

  • likelihood (str) – Parameter used to specify the model we will use as a likelihood.

  • prior (str) – Parameter used to specify the model we will use as a prior distribution.

confidence_region(likelihood: str = None, prior: str = None, mu: float = None, var: float = None, theta: float = None, a: float = 1, b: float = 1, percent: float = 90) → list[source]

A method used to calculate a bayesian confidence region.

Parameters:

  • likelihood (str) – Used to define our likelihood if it has not been defined yet.

  • prior (str) – The distribution used as the prior, if the model instance attribute is not defined we have to define it here.

  • mu (float) – Optional parameter used if the mean of the population is known.

  • var (float) – Optional parameter used if the variance of the population is known.

  • theta (float) – Parameter used as p hat for a bernoulli distribution and lambda hat for and exponential distribution.

  • a (float) – Parameter used in a Beta and Gamma distribution.

  • b (float) – Parameter used in a Beta and Gamma distribution.

Returns:

A list of our upper and lower values for our confidence region.

Return type:

List

conjugate_prior(prior: float = None, value: float = None, mu: float = None, var: float = None, theta: float = None, a: float = 1, b: float = 1) → float[source]

A method used for defining a conjugate prior distribution.

Parameters:

  • prior (str) – The distribution used as the prior, if the model instance attribute is not defined we have to define it here.

  • value (float) – The value of the probablity we want to calculate.

  • mu (float) – Optional parameter used to calculate the pdf if the mean of the population is known.

  • var (float) – Optional parameter used to calculate the pdf if the variance of the population is known.

  • theta (float) – Parameter used as p hat for a bernoulli distribution and lambda hat for and exponential distribution.

  • a (float) – Parameter used in a Beta and Gamma distribution.

  • b (float) – Parameter used in a Beta and Gamma distribution.

Returns:

A instance of an object the represents our prior distribution.

Return type:

ConjugatePrior
